content.body: ergh. I just realized I left jacket on the bus from the airport.
less funny
try to call the buscompany
Between 8 and 23
tries the email option :P
not like you'll need it this week :D
Indeed.
But the hoodie would be nice as a pillow :p
28-29* all week
goes *wheee*
yea, for once its hot WEEEE
=D
you don't have a pillow?
No
I only have bed linen at all because I asked James for some yesterday :P
eighty4: he has some hair as ive understood it
Midler: and I have to work like crazy all week
gsnedders: you need ikea
:P
I think everything else I need is supermarket stuff
ever been to ikea?
I'll think of more and more stuff tomorrow morning
Yes
they have everything :)
eighty4: Really everything in Sweden? :P
everything you need at least
and if you get hungry they have hotdogs for 5kr
Power for laundry?
:P
no, but you don't need that. Not really
jesus christ, took an hour and a half for comcast to solve my problem
including them asking for my MAC address _twice_ despite the support call being an IM session WITH A CHAT LOG
Not surprising
not surprising, but still tiresome :-)
waves tiredly
would head out and wonder, but thinks it is too likely he'll get lost
MikeSmith: yt?
could do with some breakfastâ€¦
is somewhat limited by the emptiness of this flat
what's the status on HTML comment tags?
For example, in a page i was recently it had:
<!-- comment > text <a href=...>
And althought the comment wasn't properly closed with a "-->", the text appeared
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/HowToWriteASpec is nice; hopefully someone will use it :)
http://itpastorn.blogspot.com/2009/06/validation-and-doctype-myths-and.html - <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "null" "null"> - oops
ouch, that page argues for using window.open rather than target=_blank
wow
"Ian, I don't think that it is fair to imply or assert that longdesc and
summary
do not work in practice."
(http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Jun/0767.html)
I'm not quite sure who it would be unfair to to assert that longdesc doesn't work in practice
takkaria: I guess the argument is: UA vendors are consulted on whether features work. In the case of accessibility features, AT vendors are a key class of UA vendors who should be consulted.
(it somewhat sidesteps the problematic nature of actually consulting AT vendors)
takkaria: The point about many "bad" summary values not being presented to the user in practice could be taken as an example of the benefits of such consultation.
I was more heading at the longdesc bit
I mean, there is no data anywhere that supports the idea that longdesc is a useful part of the web platform
The same may be true of longdesc; the longdesc lottery article didn't (IIRC) test or consult as to what longdesc values are or aren't presented to users.
Morning/afternoon.  Is there some way to make this page split into smaller sections?  Firefox lags in general when this page is opened.  http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/
(There may be additional problems with the longdesc/summary values /actually/ presented to users, of course.)
Wolfman2000: add multipage/ on the end of the url
Wolfman2000: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/
indeed not, but I did some of the original research for that article, and I really don't know how you can conclude that longdesc works in practice
That works.  Thanks.
you can't just go around saying "I don't think it's fair to assert that x" when everything speaks for that assertion and nothing against it
Hmm...Safari 4 seems to handle the singlepage/ fine
has never really bought into the evidence brought to bear in that article, but there we go.
I'm just annoyed at people casting aspersions without giving good reasons for casting them
I think the comment should have acknowledged that AT vendors are at liberty to join the discussion; and that some AT vendors are already present in the discussion.
I think there's also a big difference here between adding new features and evaluating existing features
if we introduce new a11n features, AT vendors should be consulted
but longdesc/summary are about seeing if an existing experiment has given good results or not
I don't think there's any difference really.
As we can see from summary, consultation can change one's interpretation of existing features.
Murray's argument just seem to be suggesting to me that the AT people should say what a11n features we should have, and that's that
takkaria: I'm not sure that is what Murray is arguing.
maybe I'm wilfully misinterpreting given my own biases :)
takkaria: Seems to me his argument is: if browser vendors are the ultimate arbiters of features, then why are AT arbiters not the ultimate arbiters of a11y features.
(earlier in the email he rejects the idea that browser vendors can be trusted to get things right for their users)
well, they are
but the AT vendors tend to refuse to take part in the HTMLWG, so there's not much can be done about that...
some AT vendors.
there are certainly options for external consultation
particularly with opensource projects like NVDA and Orca.
And to some extent that's happening, if perhaps only rather indirectly - I know e.g. jgraham has been chatting with Marco Zehe (Mozilla a11y, ex-Freedom Scientific guy) in here.
mm
I'm just not sure we need AT people to be there to see that longdesc has failed on the web

Personally, I find the idea of putting a11y features into a box and putting it at the feet of AT vendors as problematic as it would be to exclude the later from discussions of supposedly non-a11y features.
there's a lot of accessibility that has little to do with AT.
but is provided by authoring practice or ordinary browser features.
I think the argument about the utility of "summary" to sighted users (however we choose to judge on that issue) touches directly on that.
webben: It also reinforces the view of accessibility as a bolt-on thing
Dashiva: well the idea of "a11y feature" is itself the idea of a bolt-on thing.
I don't think the notion "a11y features" might be the province of AT vendors adds much bolt-on-ed-ness.
The idea itself is author bolt-on, but leaving it to AT makes it a vendor bolt-on too.
I see what you mean.
Thinking mainly of ARIA, but there might be other cases
ARIA, whatever its merits, is indeed an example of AT- rather than accessibility-driven design. But then it was basically conceived as a bolt-on to Dojo widgets so that's not surprising.
huh, I see that inputmode was removed
in favor of -waf-format-mode or some such
is there an HTML5 way to do predictOn/predictOff ?
http://thevideobay.org/ - "TVB aims to use the new HTML5 features, more specificly the <video> and <audio> tags with the ogg/theora video and audio formats"
sayrer, it wasn't removed in favor of anything
sayrer, iirc it was removed because the sole reason we had it was because of XForms
annevk2: the checkin comment says something else
http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/commit-watchers-whatwg.org/2008/001395.html
I found that the carrington mobile wordpress theme uses it
oh, interesting
looks like webkit supports it
or maybe only android?
hmm
I guess I should try predictOff
don't see any resolved webkit bugs for it
but it is in XHTML Basic
Philip`: ofcourse
maybe I should ask alex king why he put it in there
ah, looks like they added it to satisfy the mobileOk validator
wonder if any real handsets pay attention to it
